Meteor0id:

This I pull into questioning. Is this really the reason why transferring history isn’t made possible? Is it really that significant? The attacker would need full acces to your phone to link any device.

No, I guess the answer is very simple:
The way WhatsApp desktop application works, it needs to sync the complete message history, because it’s a mirror of the conversations you can see on the phone.
The way Signal desktop application works, it’s a completely independent second device, which can be used without a phone.
So syncing of old messages is completely not necessary.

I wouldn’t like it, I want to have it to way it’s rigth now.
So maybe for people, who really want to get their old messages, a new option could be added to the desktop app: Fetch message history.
This new option would have to be asked for with a Feature request first, and then to be coded, it would take some time.
So first it should be checked, how many people really need it.

Syncing could be implemented the way that you have to click a button in the synced devices list on your main Signal installation to sync to your secondary device. So a 3rd Party needs to have access to your phone to start syncing.

Right now the server just maintains separate queues for the linked and main clients. After linking, any message that is sent to you is delivered to all clients and any message that you send from one client is also sent to your other clients.

Syncing history is not the same. The main client would have to upload tons of messages. Moving backup between different platforms is probably better. It also reduces any security risk of clients getting linked without your knowledge.

BTW, is there a note to self chat in the desktop client and does that sync?

Meteor0id:

I suspect the real reason why history is not transferred is the technical and capacity difficulties which need to be overcome to make it possible, instead of a security reason.

Why I think it isn’t reasonable to “sync” all previous message history:

  • You could have 1000s of messages. For each linked device you would need to transfer them. Regardless of whether that is done via the Signal service or somehow peer-to-peer, it’s likely going to take a lot of time. The user will not wait for this.
  • Let’s say you figured out how to sync this in the background, and starting from the latest message, so the user gets the perception that all of the history is already here. Not only would that be false (and thus cause confusion, unless you put some alert saying “not everything is synced” at the top? they might not scroll to see it and disconnect either device from the network, expecting to be able to read all history…), but in any case that’d waste a lot of power (and potentially mobile data or other metered connection data!) from all devices participating in this process.

The only thing I imagine could work is loading messages on demand (like I imagine WA works as I said above) and storing already loaded ones. The device will become less independent (at least in perception) however — it’ll require your phone to be online in the case you are trying to read past messages which haven’t yet been synced…

posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked: Yes, those are technical, practical and capacity issues. But what is this security argument which Signal currenly mentions? I think the app should be straight forward honest to users about why transfering isn’t possible. It has nothing to do with security that I can think of.

Meteor0id:

that linked device would need a copy of the key on my phone in order to decrypt messages.

This is not correct,
the way Signal works is quite different than the way you think.

I’ll quote myself:

Signal Android/iOS on your phone does not share the same cue with any instance of Signal on any desktop.
Each and every Signal Desktop instance that you link to your main app (on telephone) will have a separate cue as well as it’s unique encryption keys. And that cue will be created at the moment you link that Desktop instance to you phone app. Before that moment the cue doesn’t exist at all.

When anybody sends you a message, their app will send copies of that message to all your Signal instances (phone + one or more desktop) encrypted with their relevant keys, and those will go in individual cues on the server until delivered, and then immediately deleted.

So, any message sent to/from you before a Desktop app is linked to your main Signal app, will never reach Desktop because it was NOT sent to an instance that did NOT exist at the time the message was sent.

In practice, to achieve your goal of syncing history, each and every single message, including read receipts, reactions, huge media attachments, should be re-encrypted and re-transmitted from your phone to the newly linked Desktop client.
As someone already noted, this will be a huge waste of battery power and data not to mention the additional load on Signal servers.

“For your security…” in the message that sparked this whole thread, is possibly referred to the way other platforms work.
Meaning that Signal “For your security” does not store your data in the company’s cloud servers like FB, Telegram, Wechat and most others do.

My two cents.

posts.name: Josh Triplett
posts.cooked:
I ran into this as well, today. I tried Signal Desktop for the first time, hoping to have an integrated experience comparable to other messengers that have both phone apps and web apps. (In particular, I wanted to be able to type messages with a real keyboard.)

Upon installing and linking, I saw the message that “chat history will not be synced to this device”. My first thought was “OK, thanks for warning me, now how do I fix that?”. After searching through all the settings on both devices, I didn’t find any option to do so, and then after searching online I found that this feature doesn’t seem to exist.

I’d be happy to wait a while for the messages to transfer (ideally while being able to use the messenger, but I could live with it even if I couldn’t). I’d be happy to carefully read something telling me all the reasons I might not want to sync all my messages, and then say “yes, really, I want the desktop app to have all my messages”; certainly I can understand having the ability to not sync history, and I can imagine some people not wanting that. I’d be happy to type in my Signal PIN. I could even live with having to have my phone on and connected in order to use the desktop app, if necessary, though ideally I’d rather not. But for me, having full history available is a fundamental part of any communication app I use. I love the idea of having that history exclusively on my own devices, not anywhere else, but I do want it on all my devices, not just some of them.

In the absence of full sync between devices, I’m now unlinking and uninstalling Signal Desktop, because it doesn’t give me the full history of my chats. The net result of this is that I’ll continue to use Signal less, and text messages more, because I have the full history of my text messages available on my desktop, and because I can type text messages with a real keyboard.

JoshTriplett:

I have the full history of my text messages available on my desktop

And so do so many other entities.
